dataset.title: MCR LTER: Coral Reef: Effects of Flow and Temperature on Growth and Photophysiology of Scleractinian Corals in Moorea, French Polynesia

address.deliveryPoint: Department of Biology, California State University

abstract.para: To test for threshold effects in the response of coral physiology to increasing seawater flow, field and laboratory experiments were conducted in Moorea. First, the growth of juvenile massive Porites spp. and branching P. irregularis was compared among habitats differing in water motion. Growth of massive Porites spp. responded to flow in a pattern consistent with a threshold effect, whereas growth of P. irregularis increased linearly with flow. Second, a recirculating flume was used to test the effect of flow on photophysiology (ΔF⁄Fm'), effective photochemical efficiency) for massive Porites spp.; ΔF⁄Fm' displayed a threshold response at 23 cm/sec and 28 °C, but not at 31 °C. Finally, intra-colony variation in the response of ΔF⁄Fm' to flow and temperature was explored to evaluate the functional significance of colony shape in small corals. ΔF⁄Fm' on the top and upstream surfaces of massive Porites spp. responded with a threshold effect of flow at 28 °C (but not 31 °C), but ΔF⁄Fm' on downstream surfaces was unresponsive to flow. ΔF⁄Fm' for P. irregularis was less responsive to flow than for massive Porites spp., suggesting that the photophysiological response of corals to varying flow speeds may differ between species and morphologies. Together, these results emphasize that flow can have diverse effects on the physiology of corals, with the outcome depending on flow speed, temperature, location on the colony, and perhaps morphology.
These data were published in The Biological Bulletin and were part of the masters thesis of W. Goldenheim (2011).

keywordSet.keyword: Richard B. Gump South Pacific Research Station

intellectualRights.para:
Data collected under the auspices of the MCR LTER are available to the public after primary publication, or at most two years after the completion of the study unless proprietary restrictions are warranted. Use of MCR LTER data is subject to acceptance of the following conditions:
1. The user agrees to provide valid name and contact information prior to downloading online data. This information will be used to contact the user in case of changes to the data, and may also be used by data set authors and MCR LTER project administrators to document data usage.
2. The user agrees to cite the data set author and MCR LTER in all publications in which the data are used, as per the instructions in the data documentation. If no specific instructions are provided in the data documentation, the user is requested to include the following statement: "Data sets were provided by the Moorea Coral Reef Ecosystem LTER, funded by the US National Science Foundation (OCE-0417412)."
3. The user agrees to provide one copy of any manuscript based on MCR LTER data to the data set author prior to submitting it for publication.
4. The user agrees to send two hard copies of any published manuscript based on MCR LTER data to the following address: Dr. Andrew J. Brooks Deputy Program Director, MCR LTER Marine Science Institute University of California Santa Barbara, CA 93106-6150 The user also agrees to send one electronic copy (pdf format) to the following e-mail address: brooks@msi.ucsb.edu
5. Users are prohibited from selling or redistributing any data provided by MCR LTER without explicit prior permission.
6. Users are encouraged to contact original investigators responsible for data. Where appropriate, researchers whose projects are integrally dependent on MCR LTER data are encouraged to consider collaboration and/or co-authorship with original investigators.
7. Extensive efforts are made to ensure that online data are accurate and up to date, but the authors and the MCR LTER will not take responsibility for any errors that may exist in data provided online. Furthermore, the user assumes all responsibility for errors in analysis or judgment resulting from use of the data.
8. Any violation of the terms of this agreement will result in immediate forfeiture of the data and loss of access privileges to other MCR LTER data sets.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: North shore study area for thesis

description.para: This was a one-time study as part of a masters thesis.

section.title: Field Manipulation
section.para: All research was completed in Moorea, French Polynesia, during April and May 2008 and January 2009. A 1 month in situ expierment was used to test for a threshold effect of flow on the growth of juvenile colonies (<4 cm diameter) of masssive Porites spp. and branches of P. irregularis.

We measured flow speed in the lagoon in three locations by timing the passage of neutrally buoyant objects parallel to the direction of flow, and recorded measurements over 1 hour on each of 2 days in April and January 2009. Corals were collected from the back reef at 1–2 m depth during April 2008. Juvenile colonies (<4 cm diameter) of massive Porites spp. were collected from horizontal substrata, and branches (<4 cm length) of P. irregularis were broken off colonies. The corals were attached upright to plastic tiles using epoxy (Z-Spar A788). Initial boyant-weight was taken. Ten colonies of massive Porites spp. and 8 P. irregularis were deployed on 14 April 2008. One coral was nailed to the top of a coral bommie in vacant space, with one species per bommie. All bommies were more than 1 meter apart, parallel to the reef crest, and had upper surfaces at a 12 m depth.

After 1 month, the corals were collected and again buoyant-weighed. The difference between final and initial buoyant weights was converted to dry weight using an aragonite density of 2.93 g cm-3 (Davies, 1989), and used as a measure of growth. The surface area of the corals was measured by wax dipping (Stimson and Kinzie, 1991), and growth was normalized by area (g cm-2 month-1) and colony (g colony-1 month-1). Two means of normalizing growth were used to strengthen comparisons with previous work in which coral growth has frequently been standardized by area or colony.

section.title: Flume Trials
section.para: A recirculating flume was used to test for the effects of flow speed and temperature on the photophysiology of Symbiodinium spp. in massive Porites spp. and individual branches of P. irregularis.

The design for experiments in the flume included an ambient temperature treatment at about 28.3 °C (maximum ~29.0 °C), which was close to mean ambient seawater temperature when the study was completed (April to May 2008 ~28.5 °C) and a high temperature treatment at about 31.1 °C (maximum ~31.9°C), which is close to the maximum recorded in the lagoon (~32 °C). For each temperature treatment, five flow speeds were tested (0.0, 7.7, 14.5, 23.0, and 33.0 cm s-1) to characterize the functional relationtionship between DeltaF/F m'.

Juvenile colonies of massive Porites spp. were collected from depths of 1–2 m in the back reef, and branches of P. irregularis were collected from 1–3 m on fringing reefs. Flume experiments with massive Porites spp. were completed in April and May 2008, and for P. irregularis, in January 2009.

section.title: Statistical Analysis
section.para: Tests of the effects of flow and temperature on DeltaF/F m' were completed with two approaches. For DeltaF/F m' of the top of massive Porites spp., a 2 way ANOVA was used in which flow speed and temerature were fixed factors, DeltaF/F m' was the dependent variable, and each colony was treated as a statistical replicate. To test the hypothesis of intra-colony variation in the response of DeltaF/F m' to flow and temperature, a 3-way ANOVA was used in which flow speed, temperature, and position on colony (i.e., upstream vs. downstream) were fixed factors.

dataTable.entityDescription: These data were published in Table 1 and Fig. 2 of Goldenheim and Edmunds 2011, Biological Bulletin.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Habitat within the lagoon site on the North shore of Moorea. Lagoon contains reef crest, backreef, and fringing reef habitats.

codeDefinition.definition: Reef Crest is at the boundary between backreef and forereef
Back Reef is toward shore from the reef crest, also called backreef
Fringe Reef is along the shoreline, also called Fringing Reef

attribute.attributeDefinition: Genus and species of the coral that was measured.
Initial buoyant weight reports the buoyant weight prior to deployment of the corals in the field
Final buoyant weight reports the buoyant weight after collection from the field ~1 month later

dataTable.entityDescription: These data were published in Table 1 and Fig. 2 of Goldenheim and Edmunds 2011, Biological Bulletin.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Habitat within the lagoon site on the North shore of Moorea. Lagoon contains reef crest, backreef, and fringing reef habitats.

codeDefinition.definition: Reef Crest is at the boundary between backreef and forereef

attribute.attributeDefinition: Arbitrary unique identifier for each coral.
Gensus and species of the coral that was measured.
Change in weight (i.e. growth) of corals using change in bouyant weight corrected to dry weight knowing the density of aragonite that makes the coral skeleton.
Estimated surface area of the corals.
Growth rates standardized to area during experimental period on the reef.
Logarithmic transformations of growth rates.

dataTable.entityDescription: These data were published in Fig. 3 and Fig. 4 for massive Porites spp. of Goldenheim and Edmunds 2011, Biological Bulletin.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Temperature of the seawater in the flume, ambient or high
Flume motor setting, which is calibrated based on the data on the Flume calibration sheet.
Location on the colony relative to unidirectional flow.
Basal fluorescence value, a photophysiology measurement made by the PAM fluorometer for dark-adapted yields.
Maximum fluorescence value, a photophysiology measurement made by the PAM fluorometer for dark-adapted yields.
Ratio of upstream (Fm-Fo)/Fm for dark adapted yields
Basal fluorescence value, a photophysiology measurement made by the PAM fluorometer for light-adapted yields.
